name: 350.org
mission: 350.org is building a global grassroots climate movement that can hold our leaders accountable to the realities of science and the principles of justice. That movement is rising from the bottom up all over the world, and is uniting to create the solutions that will ensure a better future for all. Our online campaigns, grassroots organizing, and mass public actions bring together a global network active in over 188 countries
theoryOfChange: 350.org has a published Theory of Change document, which outlines how their work aims to achieve their desired impact. This framework brings together their vision for the world, the purpose of 350.org in meeting that vision, and the goals and strategies they employ. The document states that 350.org believes governments and corporations will not adequately address climate change without pressure from an organized movement. Their approach involves galvanizing public support, countering vested interests, and demonstrating alternative pathways to a thriving global community. The mission is to inspire, train, and mobilize people to join a broad climate movement that challenges systems leading to catastrophic climate change and moves towards a just and sustainable future. They emphasize building the climate movement through engaging and connecting people, deepening their commitment, and involving them in groundbreaking campaigns.

evaluationSources: Philanthropedia (highest rated organization working on climate change)
One Green Planet (Top 10 Most Influential Environmental Campaigns)

all_citations.claim: 350.org reported a total revenue of $19,587,115 and detailed its program expenses.
The audited financial statements confirm the organization's revenue and expense allocations for the 2024 fiscal year.
The charity accepts general donations for climate impact and advocacy work.
Historical financial data shows consistent focus on US campaigning and global mobilization.
350.org holds a score of 99.66666666666667/100 for its financial health, accountability, and transparency.

baseline_narrative.amal_score_rationale: 350.org earns a moderate overall score due to its exceptional financial health and transparency, balanced against its specific focus on advocacy which may not align with all donor preferences.
areas_for_improvement: Limited direct alignment for donors seeking traditional faith-based charitable frameworks
Impact measurement is focused on capacity building and advocacy rather than direct service delivery

dimension_explanations.alignment: While the organization is a leader in the urgent cause of climate advocacy, its alignment with specific Muslim donor preferences is considered low as it is a secular advocacy group [6][8]. Contributions are classified as Sadaqah-eligible, supporting general environmental welfare and social justice initiatives [6].
dimension_explanations.impact: The organization demonstrates high effectiveness in its operational model, maintaining a Charity Navigator score of 99.66666666666667/100 [8]. With a program expense ratio of 81.5%, the majority of its $19,587,115 revenue directly supports its mission of training and mobilizing climate activists [1][2]. Its impact is primarily categorized as capacity building, focusing on systemic change rather than direct beneficiary aid [8].

baseline_narrative.headline: 350.org mobilizes a global grassroots movement to challenge the systems driving the climate crisis through advocacy and training.
strengths: High financial efficiency with a program expense ratio of 81.5%
Strong fundraising efficiency, spending only $0.12 per $1 raised
Robust liquidity with 7.2 months of working capital available
baseline_narrative.summary: 350.org is an international environmental organization dedicated to building a diverse climate movement that promotes renewable energy solutions and challenges fossil fuel dependency [1][8]. The organization reported a total revenue of $19,587,115 and focuses its resources on training, mobilizing, and campaigning for climate justice [1][7].

all_citations.quote: We have audited the consolidated financial statements of 350.org

rich_narrative.amal_score_rationale: 350.org earns a moderate overall score due to its exceptional financial health and transparency, balanced against its specific focus on advocacy which may not align with all donor preferences.

areas_for_improvement.context: The organization has seen a <cite id="7">3-year revenue CAGR of -8.0%</cite>, indicating a contraction in annual funding that may impact long-term scaling.
While advocacy is inherently difficult to quantify, the organization currently <cite id="8">lacks specific beneficiary counts</cite> which limits cost-per-beneficiary analysis.

bbb_assessment.summary: The organization provides <cite id="2">audited financial statements</cite> and maintains high transparency through Candid and Charity Navigator.

case_against.mitigation_notes: The organization maintains high reserves (7.2 months) to mitigate the impact of revenue fluctuations.
risk_factors: <cite id="7">Negative 8.0% revenue growth</cite> over the last three years
<cite id="8">No direct beneficiary data</cite> available for cost analysis
case_against.summary: The primary concerns involve <cite id="7">declining revenue trends</cite> and the inherent difficulty in measuring the direct impact of advocacy-based work.

confidence.notes: Very high transparency and third-party verification.

alignment.explanation: While the cause of climate justice is urgent, there is <cite id="8">low specific alignment for Muslim donors</cite> as the organization does not offer faith-based giving frameworks.
alignment.improvement: The organization could <cite id="8">highlight the humanitarian dimensions</cite> of climate change in Muslim-majority regions to better resonate with this donor base.

credibility.explanation: 350.org is highly credible, evidenced by its <cite id="8">4-star rating from Charity Navigator</cite> and a <cite id="8">Gold Seal of Transparency</cite>. They utilize <cite id="2">independent audits</cite> to verify their global operations.
credibility.improvement: To further enhance credibility, the organization could pursue BBB Wise Giving Alliance accreditation to verify all 20 standards of accountability.

impact.explanation: Impact is driven by a <cite id="8">81.5% program ratio</cite> and a <cite id="8">strong theory of change</cite> focused on capacity building and systemic advocacy.
impact.improvement: Impact measurement would benefit from <cite id="8">tracking and reporting specific beneficiary counts</cite> to enable more granular cost-effectiveness analysis.

rich_narrative.headline: 350.org mobilizes a global grassroots movement to challenge the systems driving the climate crisis through advocacy and training.

ideal_donor_profile.best_for_summary: Best for donors who prioritize systemic climate advocacy over direct service and value high financial transparency in global movements.
donor_motivations: Want to challenge the systems driving the climate crisis
Value grassroots mobilization and leadership training
Prefer funding advocacy and divestment over local service delivery
Seek organizations with top-tier accountability ratings
giving_considerations: Donations support long-term policy and systemic shifts
Impact is measured through movement growth rather than individual aid
The organization is currently navigating a period of revenue contraction
ideal_donor_profile.not_ideal_for: Donors seeking to fulfill Zakat obligations or those looking for immediate, tangible humanitarian relief metrics.

impact_evidence.evidence_grade_explanation: The organization has a <cite id="8">verified theory of change</cite> and high transparency, though advocacy outcomes are harder to quantify than direct aid.
impact_evidence.theory_of_change_summary: 350.org mobilizes a global movement to <cite id="8">challenge fossil fuel systems</cite> through training, divestment, and renewable energy advocacy.
impact_evidence.why_evidence_matters: Evidence in advocacy ensures that mobilization efforts are successfully targeting the systemic drivers of climate change.

long_term_outlook.room_for_funding_explanation: As a global movement-builder, 350.org can absorb significant capital to expand its <cite id="8">leadership training and regional campaigns</cite>.

organizational_capacity.geographic_reach: Global operations including India, Brazil, and Australia

peer_comparison.differentiator: Distinguished by a <cite id="8">higher program expense ratio (81.5%)</cite> compared to the <cite id="8">peer median of 81.5%</cite>.

strengths.detail: The organization maintains a <cite id="8">perfect 100/100 score in both Culture and Leadership</cite> from Charity Navigator, alongside a <cite id="8">99/100 for Accountability</cite>.
With a <cite id="8">program expense ratio of 81.5%</cite>, 350.org exceeds the <cite id="8">peer program ratio median of 81.5%</cite> for advocacy organizations.
The charity spends only <cite id="8">$0.12 to raise every $1</cite>, demonstrating highly effective resource mobilization.

strengths_deep_dive: 350.org's operational strength lies in its ability to maintain high liquidity and transparency while managing a complex global network. The organization holds <cite id="8">7.2 months of working capital</cite>, providing a robust buffer for long-term campaigning. Their commitment to transparency is evidenced by a <cite id="7">Gold Seal of Transparency from Candid</cite> and the publication of <cite id="2">audited financial statements</cite>. Furthermore, the governance structure is highly independent, with <cite id="8">100% independent board members</cite> overseeing a diverse portfolio of climate finance and renewable energy programs.
rich_narrative.summary: Founded in <cite id="8">2008</cite>, 350.org has grown into a global grassroots powerhouse dedicated to ending the fossil fuel era and transitioning to renewable energy. The organization operates on a significant scale, reporting <cite id="7">$19,587,115 in total revenue</cite> for the most recent fiscal year. Unlike direct-service charities, 350.org focuses on systemic change through <cite id="8">advocacy, climate leadership training, and divestment movements</cite>. Their financial management is notably efficient for the advocacy sector, maintaining a <cite id="8">program expense ratio of 81.5%</cite>, which ensures that the vast majority of donor funds are directed toward campaigning and movement building rather than administrative overhead. The organization has achieved a <cite id="8">99.66666666666667/100 overall score from Charity Navigator</cite>, reflecting a near-perfect balance of accountability and financial health. While their work is global, they maintain a strong domestic presence, distributing <cite id="7">$517,500 in domestic grants</cite> to local chapters like 350 Seattle and 350 Bay Area to fuel localized climate action.
